item.title: April 4th is Deletion Day
item.description:
I included the following in my application for SFPC:

DELETION, PERMANENCE, AND CONSISTENCY=====================================

Silicon Valley likes to store data because it entrenches people in their past behaviors. Corporate culture‚Äôs emphasis on consistency is ableist, colonizing, transphobic, and represents a growing discomfort with people‚Äôs fluidity.

I hope someday to have an International Day of Deletion. How can we live more presently?

I am excited to say that after a few years of privately practicing Deletion Day on April 4th, we‚Äôve got a public website.

Deletion Day 2020 is less straightforward than it‚Äôs been in past years. With the isolation of social distancing, I‚Äôve found comfort in social and digital media. And my gripes about data security and privacy seem tiny next to the health crisis we‚Äôre dealing with globally. But ‚Äì this is still something that matters to me. Privacy and agency remain important components of the rapid changes we‚Äôre witnessing in government and society.

item.title: final showcase project: depression
item.description:
‚Äúhow can i help?‚Äù

a solitary dial reflects the machine‚Äôs physical clock speed, acting as display rather than control. despite appearances, your presence is appreciated.

depression is a personal reflection of my past few years, struggling with depression in an environment that couldn‚Äôt help or support me the way i needed. depression initially existed as part of a larger criticism of capitalism and the work ethic. i stripped down the larger piece until one exposed dial remained.

the dial represents the machine‚Äôs energy level. turned all the way down, it represents depression; the machine‚Äôs clock speed drops, and it becomes so sluggish it‚Äôs nearly inoperational. when the dial is turned all the way up, the machine works ‚Äúas intended‚Äù.

item.title: Telepresence Manifesto (2018 redux)
item.description:
today in critical theory, we read and discussed a few ‚Äúmanifestos for the internet age‚Äù. i‚Äôve got a cold so i called in; when the class broke out to create their own manifestos, i decided to write a ‚Äútelepresence manifesto‚Äù from my sniffly blanket fort.

turns out marvin minsky beat me to it. for context: minsky, who said ‚Äúi don‚Äôt think there is any such thing‚Äù regarding human consciousness, co-founded MIT‚Äôs AI laboratory. item.title: rough thoughts on the bear thing
item.description:
it was silly to write all of this down but i created this blog today and i‚Äôm still editing the layout, so i want more words to work with.

create a few distinct sounds, for example:

  • cup/table tap
  • cup/table scrape
  • ball/table tap
  • ball/table scrape
  • cup/ball tap

these examples are unambiguous and easy to perform rapidly by someone keeping the cup in one hand & ball in the other. i‚Äôll refer to each performed sound as a ‚Äúbit‚Äù from here on out.

for n bits, you have (number of sounds)^n options. with the examples above that‚Äôs 5^n, which is plenty.

so what‚Äôs important to convey?

the shapes are curvy and strange, so it‚Äôs easier to share a limited reference table of basic + advanced shapes instead of deriving each part of the bear from scratch. three bits could cover 125 shapes, which is ample for bear and bear-like drawings.

item.title: Graphing depth
item.description:
There‚Äôs something magical about a procedure that just works. Even if you don‚Äôt understand why it works, having a set of steps that will always get you to the same destination feels nice. In life there are few patterns that consistently produce the same outcome. But in math? Hoo boy‚Ä¶ This post takes us through two very simple procedures that converge to a numerical endpoint. We‚Äôre going to graph the amount of time it takes to reach this endpoint, which actually ends up being quite pretty.

item.description:
